test_questions.question: With which network type will OSPF establish router adjacencies but not perform the DR/BDR election process?
test_questions.explanation: No DR is assigned on any type of point-to-point link. No DR/BDR is assigned on the NBMA point-to-multipoint due to the hub/spoke topology. DR and BDR are elected on broadcast and non-broadcast multi-access networks. Frame Relay is a non-broadcast multi-access (NBMA) network by default.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following describe the process identifier that is used to run OSPF on a router?
  It is locally significant.
  It is globally significant.
  It is needed to identify a unique instance of an OSPF database.
  It is an optional parameter required only if multiple OSPF processes are running on the router.
test_questions.explanation: The Process ID for OSPF on a router is only locally significant and you can use the same number on each router, or each router can have a different number-it just doesn't matter. The numbers you can use are from 1 to 65,535. Don't get this confused with area numbers, which can be from 0 to 4.2 billion.

test_questions.question: A network administrator needs to configure a router with a distance-vector protocol that allows classless routing. Which of the following satisfies those requirements?
test_questions.explanation: In this question, we're calling EIGRP just plain old distance vector. EIGRP is an "advanced" distance-vector routing protocol, sometimes called a hybrid routing protocol because it uses the characteristics of both distance-vector and link-state routing protocols.

test_questions.question: What is the administrative distance of OSPF?
test_questions.explanation: The administrative distance (AD) is a very important parameter in a routing protocol. The lower the AD, the more trusted the route. If you have IGRP and OSPF running, by default IGRP routes would be placed in the routing table because IGRP has a lower AD of 100. OSPF has an AD of 110. RIPv1 and RIPv2 both have an AD of 120, and EIGRP is the lowest, at 90.

test_questions.question: Your company is running IGRP using an AS of 10. You want to configure EIGRP on the network but want to migrate slowly to EIGRP and don't want to configure redistribution. What command would allow you to migrate over time to EIGRP without configuring redistribution?
test_questions.explanation: If you enable EIGRP on a router with the same autonomous system (AS) number, EIGRP will automatically redistribute IGRP into EIGRP. You will see the IGRP injected routes as external (EX) routes with an EIGRP AD of 170. This is a nice feature that lets you migrate slowly to EIGRP with no extra configuration.

test_questions.question: Where are EIGRP successor routes stored?
test_questions.optd: In the routing table and the topology table
test_questions.opte: In the routing table and the neighbor table
test_questions.explanation: Successor routes are going to be in the routing table since they are the best path to a remote network. However, the topology table has a link to each and every network, so the best answer is topology table and routing table. Any secondary route to a remote network is considered a feasible successor, and those routes are only found in the topology table and used as backup routes in case of primary route failure.

test_questions.question: Which command will display all the EIGRP feasible successor routes known to a router?
test_questions.explanation: Any secondary route to a remote network is considered a feasible successor, and those routes are only found in the topology table and used as backup routes in case of primary route failure. You can see the topology table with the show ip eigrp topology command.

test_questions.question:
Which is true regarding EIGRP successor routes?
  A successor route is used by EIGRP to forward traffic to a destination.
  Successor routes are saved in the topology table to be used if the primary route fails.
  Successor routes are flagged as "active" in the routing table.
  A successor route may be backed up by a feasible successor route.
  Successor routes are stored in the neighbor table following the discovery process.
test_questions.explanation: Successor routes are the routes picked from the topology table as the best route to a remote network, so these are the routes that IP uses in the routing table to forward traffic to a remote destination. The topology table contains any route that is not as good as the successor route and is considered a feasible successor, or backup route. Remember that all routes are in the topology table, even successor routes.

test_questions.question:
Which EIGRP information is held in RAM and maintained through the use of Hello and update packets?
  Neighbor table
  STP table
  Topology table
  DUAL table
test_questions.explanation: EIGRP holds three tables in RAM: neighbor, topology, and routing. The neighbor and topology tables are built and maintained with the use of Hello packets.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are true regarding OSPF areas?
  You must have separate loopback interfaces configured in each area.
  The numbers you can assign an area go up to 65,535.
  The backbone area is also called area 0.
  If your design is hierarchical, then you don't need multiple areas.
  All areas must connect to area 0.
test_questions.explanation: Loopback interfaces are created on a router, and the highest IP address on a loopback (logical) interface becomes the RID of the router but has nothing to do with areas and is optional, so (1) is wrong. The numbers you can create an area with are from 0 to 4,294,967,295 option (2) is wrong. The backbone area is called area 0, so option (3) is correct. All areas must connect to area 0, so option (5) is correct. If you have only one area, it must be called area 0. This leaves option (4), which must be correct; it doesn't make much sense, but it is the best answer.

test_questions.question:
What are reasons for creating OSPF in a hierarchical design?
  To decrease routing overhead
  To speed up convergence
  To confine network instability to single areas of the network
  To make configuring OSPF easier
test_questions.explanation: OSPF is created in a hierarchical design, not a flat design like RIP. This decreases routing overhead, speeds up convergence, and confines network instability to a single area of the network.

test_questions.question:
Which two of the following commands will place network 10.2.3.0/24 into area 0?
 router eigrp 10
 router ospf 10
 network 10.0.0.0
 network 10.2.3.0 0.0.0.255 area0
 network 10.2.3.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
test_questions.explanation: To enable OSPF, you must first start OSPF using a Process ID. The number is irrelevant; just choose a number from 1 to 65,535 and you're good to go. After you start the OSPF process, you must configure any network that you want advertised via OSPF using wildcards and the area command. Statement (4) is wrong because there must be a space after the parameter area and before you list the area number.

test_questions.question: If routers in a single area are configured with the same priority value, what value does a router use for the OSPF Router ID in the absence of a loopback interface?
test_questions.opta: The lowest IP address of any physical interface
test_questions.optb: The highest IP address of any physical interface
test_questions.optc: The lowest IP address of any logical interface
test_questions.optd: The highest IP address of any logical interface
test_questions.explanation: At the moment of OSPF process startup, the highest IP address on any active interface will be the Router ID (RID) of the router. If you have a loopback interface configured (logical interface), then that will override the interface IP address and become the RID of the router automatically.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following protocols support VLSM, summarization, and discontiguous networking? 
  RIPv1
  IGRP
  EIGRP
  OSPF
  BGP
  RIPv2
test_questions.explanation: RIPv1 and IGRP are true distance-vector routing protocols and can't do much, really-except build and maintain routing tables and use a lot of bandwidth! RIPv2, EIGRP, and OSPF build and maintain routing tables, but they also provide classless routing, which allows for VLSM, summarization, and discontiguous networking.

test_questions.question:
You get a call from a network administrator who tells you that he typed the following into his router:
Router(config)#router ospf 1
Router(config-router)#network 10.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 area 0
He tells you he still can't see any routes in the routing table. What configuration error did the administrator make?
test_questions.optc: The OSPF Process ID is incorrect.
test_questions.explanation: The administrator typed in the wrong wildcard mask configuration. The wildcard should have been 0.0.0.255.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following network types have a designated router and a backup designated router assigned?
  Broadcast
  Point-to-point
  NBMA
  NBMA point-to-point
test_questions.explanation: No DR is assigned on any type of point-to-point link. No DR/BDR is assigned on the NBMA point-to-multipoint due to the hub/spoke topology. DR and BDR are elected on broadcast and non-broadcast multi-access networks. Frame Relay is a non-Broadcast Multi-Access (NBMA) network by default.

test_questions.question:
Which type of OSPF network will elect a backup designated router?
  Broadcast multi-access
  Non-broadcast multi-access
  Point-to-point
  Broadcast multipoint
test_questions.explanation: DR and BDR are elected on broadcast and non-broadcast multi-access networks. Frame Relay is a non-broadcast multi-access (NBMA) network by default. No DR is assigned on any type of point-to-point link. No DR/BDR is assigned on the NBMA point-to-multipoint due to the hub/spoke topology.

test_questions.question: You need the IP address of the devices with which the router has established an adjacency. Also, the retransmit interval and the queue counts for the adjacent routers need to be checked. What command will display the required information?
test_questions.explanation: The show ip eigrp neighbors command allows you to check the IP addresses as well as the retransmit interval and queue counts for the neighbors that have established an adjacency.

test_questions.question:
Which layer 1 devices can be used to enlarge the area covered by a single LAN segment?
  Switch
  NIC
  Hub
  Repeater
  RJ45 transceiver
test_questions.explanation: Not that you really want to enlarge a single collision domain, but a hub (multiport repeater) will provide this for you.

test_questions.question: Routers operate at layer _____. LAN switches operate at layer _____. Ethernet hubs operate at layer _____. Word processing operates at layer _____.
test_questions.explanation: Routers operate at layer 3. LAN switches operate at layer 2. Ethernet hubs operate at layer 1. Word processing applications communicate to the Application layer interface, but do not operate at layer 7, so the answer would be none.

test_questions.question: Which of the following describe router functions?
test_questions.explanation: Routers provide packet switching, packet filtering, internetwork communication, and path selection.

test_questions.question:
Why does the data communication industry use the layered OSI reference model?
  It divides the network communication process into smaller and simpler components, thus aiding component development, design, and troubleshooting.
  It enables equipment from different vendors to use the same electronic components, thus saving research and development funds.
  It supports the evolution of multiple competing standards and thus provides business opportunities for equipment manufacturers.
  It encourages industry standardization by defining what functions occur at each layer of the model.
test_questions.explanation:
The main advantage of a layered model is that it can allow application developers to 
change aspects of a program in just one layer of the layer model's specifications. Advantages 
of using the OSI layered model include, but are not limited to, the following: It divides the 
network communication process into smaller and simpler components, thus aiding compo-
nent development, design, and troubleshooting; it allows multiple-vendor development 
through standardization of network components; it encourages industry standardization by 
defining what functions occur at each layer of the model; it allows various types of network 
hardware and software to communicate; and it prevents changes in one layer from affecting 
other layers, so it does not hamper development.

test_questions.question: A receiving host has failed to receive all of the segments that it should acknowledge. What can the host do to improve the reliability of this communication session?
test_questions.opta: Send a different source port number.
test_questions.explanation: A receiving host can control the transmitter by using flow control (TCP uses Windowing by default). By decreasing the window size, the receiving host can slow down the transmitting host so the receiving host does not overflow its buffers.

test_questions.question: What are the decimal and hexadecimal equivalents for the binary number 10110111?
test_questions.explanation:
You must be able to take a binary number and convert it into both decimal and hexadecimal. 
To convert to decimal, just add up the 1s using their values. The values that are turned on with 
the binary number of 10110111 are 128 + 32 + 16 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 183. To get the hexadecimal 
equivalent, you need to break the eight binary digits into nibbles (4 bits), 1011 and 0111. By add-
ing up these values, you get 11 and 7. In hexadecimal, 11 is B, so the answer is 0xB7.

test_questions.question: What is the purpose of flow control?
test_questions.opta: To ensure that data is retransmitted if an acknowledgment is not received.
test_questions.optb: To reassemble segments in the correct order at the destination device.
test_questions.optc: To provide a means for the receiver to govern the amount of data sent by the sender.
test_questions.optd: To regulate the size of each segment.
test_questions.explanation: Flow control allows the receiving device to control the transmitter so the receiving device's buffer does not overflow.

test_questions.question:
Which three statements are true about the operation of a full-duplex Ethernet network?
  There are no collisions in full-duplex mode.
  A dedicated switch port is required for each full-duplex node.
  Ethernet hub ports are preconfigured for full-duplex mode.
  In a full-duplex environment, the host network card must check for the availability of the network media before transmitting.
  The host network card and the switch port must be capable of operating in full-duplex mode.
test_questions.explanation: Full-duplex means you are using both wire pairs simultaneously to send and receive data. You must have a dedicated switch port for each node, which means you will not have collisions. Both the host network card and the switch port must be capable and set to work in full-duplex mode.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are types of flow control?
  Buffering
  Cut-through
  Windowing
  Congestion avoidance
test_questions.explanation: The common types of flow control are buffering, windowing, and congestion avoidance.

test_questions.question:
What are two purposes for segmentation with a bridge?
  To add more broadcast domains.
  To create more collision domains.
  To add more bandwidth for users.
  To allow more broadcasts for users.
test_questions.explanation: Bridges break up collision domains, which allow more bandwidth for users.

test_questions.question:
How does a host on an Ethernet LAN know when to transmit after a collision has occurred?
  In a CSMA/CD collision domain, multiple stations can successfully transmit data simultaneously.
  In a CSMA/CD collision domain, stations must wait until the media is not in use before transmitting.
  You can improve the CSMA/CD network by adding more hubs.
  After a collision, the station that detected the collision has first priority to resend the lost data.
  After a collision, all stations run a random backoff algorithm. When the backoff delay period has expired, all stations have equal priority to transmit data.
test_questions.explanation: Once transmitting stations on an Ethernet segment hear a collision, they send an extended jam signal to ensure that all stations recognize the collision. After the jamming is complete, each sender waits a predetermined amount of time, plus a random time. After both timers expire, they are free to transmit, but they must make sure the media is clear before transmitting and that they all have equal priority.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following types of connections can use full duplex?
  Hub to hub
  Switch to switch
  Host to host
  Switch to hub
  Switch to host
test_questions.explanation: Hubs cannot run full-duplex Ethernet. Full duplex must be used on a point-to-point connection between two devices capable of running full duplex. Switches and hosts can run full duplex between each other, but a hub can never run full duplex.

test_questions.question: Acknowledgments, sequencing, and flow control are characteristics of which OSI layer?
test_questions.explanation: A reliable Transport layer connection uses acknowledgments to make sure all data is transmitted and received reliably. A reliable connection is defined by a virtual circuit that uses acknowledgments, sequencing, and flow control, which are characteristics of the Transport layer (layer 4).

test_questions.question:
Which fields are contained within an IEEE Ethernet frame header?
  Source and destination MAC address
  Source and destination network address
  Source and destination MAC address and source and destination network address
  FCS field
test_questions.explanation: An Ethernet frame has source and destination MAC addresses, an Ether-Type field to identify the Network layer protocol, the data, and the FCS field that holds the answer to the CRC.

test_questions.question: What type of RJ45 UTP cable do you use to connect a PC's COM port to a router or switch console port?
test_questions.explanation: To connect to a router or switch console port, you would use an RJ45 UTP rolled cable.

test_questions.question: How to implement a network medium that is not susceptible to EMI. Which type of cabling should you use?
test_questions.explanation: Fiber-optic cable provides a more secure, long-distance cable that is not susceptible to EMI interference at high speeds.

test_questions.question: Segmentation of a data stream happens at which layer of the OSI model?
test_questions.explanation: The Transport layer receives large data streams from the upper layers and breaks these up into smaller pieces called segments.

test_questions.question: When data is encapsulated, which is the correct order?
test_questions.explanation: The encapsulation method is data, segment, packet, frame, bit.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are unique characteristics of half-duplex Ethernet when compared to full-duplex Ethernet?
  Half-duplex Ethernet operates in a shared collision domain.
  Half-duplex Ethernet operates in a private collision domain.
  Half-duplex Ethernet has higher effective throughput.
  Half-duplex Ethernet has lower effective throughput.
test_questions.explanation: Unlike full duplex, half-duplex Ethernet operates in a shared collision domain, and it has a lower effective throughput than full duplex.

test_questions.question: What type of RJ45 UTP cable is used between switches?
test_questions.optd: Crossover with a router in between the two switches
test_questions.explanation: To connect two switches together, you would use a RJ45 UTP crossover cable.

test_questions.question: Which of the following commands sets the secret password to Cisco?
test_questions.explanation: The enable secret password is case sensitive, so the second option is wrong. To set the enable secret <password>, use the enable secret <password> command from global configuration mode.

test_questions.question:
You type the following command into the router and receive the following output:
Router#show serial 0/0
        ^
% Invalid input detected at '^' marker.
Why was this error message displayed?
test_questions.opta: You need to be in privileged mode.
test_questions.optb: You cannot have a space between serial and 0/0.
test_questions.optc: The router does not have a serial0/0 interface.
test_questions.optd: Part of the command is missing.
test_questions.explanation: You can view the interface statistics from user mode, but the command is show interface serial 0/0.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following commands will display the current IP addressing and the layer 1 and 2 status of an interface?
 show version
 show protocols
 show interfaces
 show controllers
 show ip interface
test_questions.explanation: The commands show protocols, show interfaces, and show ip interface will show you the layer 1 and 2 status and the IP addresses of your router's interfaces.

test_questions.question:
You type show running-config and get this output:
[output cut]
Line console 0
    Exec-timeout 1 35
    Password BIXPASSWD
    Login
[output cut]

What do the two numbers following the exec-timeout command mean?
test_questions.opta: If no command has been typed in 35 seconds, the console connection will be closed.
test_questions.optb: If no router activity has been detected in 1 hour and 35 minutes, the console will be locked out.
test_questions.optc: If no commands have been typed in 1 minute and 35 seconds, the console connection will be closed.
test_questions.optd: If you're connected to the router by a Telnet connection, input must be detected within 1 minute and 35 seconds or the connection will be closed.
test_questions.explanation: The exec-timeout command is set in minutes and seconds.

test_questions.question:
What layer of the OSI model would you assume the problem is in if you type show interface serial 1 and receive the following message?
"Serial1 is down, line protocol is down."
test_questions.optd: None. It is a router problem.
test_questions.explanation: If you see that a serial interface and the protocol are both down, then you have a Physical layer problem. If you see serial1 is up, line protocol is down, then you are not receiving (Data Link) keepalives from the remote end.

test_questions.question: Which of the following commands displays the configurable parameters and statistics of all interfaces on a router?
test_questions.explanation: With the show interfaces command, you can view the configurable parameters, get statistics for the interfaces on the router, verify if the interfaces are shut down, and see the IP address of each interface.

test_questions.question: Which of the following commands will configure all the default VTY ports on a router?
test_questions.explanation: From global configuration mode, use the line vty 0 4 command to set all five default VTY lines.

test_questions.question: You need to find the broadcast address used on a LAN on your router. What command will you type into the router from user mode to find the broadcast address?
test_questions.explanation: The command show ip protocols will actually show you the broadcast address for each interface - too bad it isn't a possible answer. Your best answer is show interfaces, which will provide the IP address and mask for each interface.

test_questions.question: Which command will delete the contents of NVRAM on a router?
test_questions.explanation: The erase startup-config command erases the contents of NVRAM and will put you in setup mode if the router is restarted.

test_questions.question: What keystroke will terminate setup mode?
test_questions.explanation: You can exit setup mode at any time by using the keystroke Ctrl+C.

test_questions.question: What command do you type to save the configuration stored in RAM to NVRAM?
test_questions.explanation: To copy the running-config to NVRAM so that it will be used if the router is restarted, use the copy running-config startup-config command (copy run start for short).

test_questions.question: You type Router#sh ru and receive an % ambiguous command error. Why did you receive this message?
test_questions.opta: The command requires additional options or parameters.
test_questions.optb: There is more than one show command that starts with the letters ru.
test_questions.optc: There is no show command that starts with ru.
test_questions.optd: The command is being executed from the wrong router mode.
test_questions.explanation: The % ambiguous command error means that there is more then one possible command that starts with ru. Use a question mark to find the correct command.

test_questions.question: If you wanted administrators to see a message when logging into the router, which command would you use?
test_questions.explanation: The typical banner is a message of the day (MOTD) and is set by using the global configuration mode command banner motd.

test_questions.question: How many simultaneous Telnet sessions does a Cisco router support by default?
test_questions.explanation: Cisco routers, if they do not have the Enterprise edition of the IOS, will default to 5 simultaneous Telnet sessions.

test_questions.question:
You set the console password, but when you display the configuration, the password doesn't show up; it looks like this:
[output cut]
Line console 0
    Exec-timeout 1 44
    Password 7098C0BQR
    Login
[output cut]
What cause the password to be stored like this?
test_questions.explanation: The command service password-encryption, from global configuration mode, will encrypt the passwords.

test_questions.question: Which command will show you whether a DTE or a DCE cable is plugged into serial 0?
test_questions.explanation: The show controllers serial 0 command will show you whether either a DTE or DCE cable is connected to the interface. If it is a DCE connection, you need to add clocking with the clock rate command.

test_questions.question: You want to totally reinitialize the router and replace the current running-config with the current startup-config. What command will you use?
test_questions.explanation: To completely replace the running-config with the startup-config, you must reload the router. Note : You may have picked option C, which isn't a bad answer. Remember, though, it doesn't replace the configuration, it appends it.

test_questions.question: If you delete the contents of NVRAM and reboot the router, what mode will you be in?
test_questions.explanation: If you delete the startup-config and reload the router, the router will automatically enter setup mode. You can also type setup from privileged mode at any time.

test_questions.question:
What is the problem with an interface if you type show interface serial 0 and receive the following message?
"Serial0 is administratively down, line protocol is down."
test_questions.optb: The administrator has the interface shut down.
test_questions.optc: The administrator is pinging from the interface.
test_questions.explanation: If an interface is shut down, the show interface command will show the interface as administratively shut down. (It is possible that no cable is attached, but you can't tell that from this message.)

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing a multicast address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: Packets are delivered to all interfaces identified by the address. This is also called a one-to-many address.
test_questions.optc: Identifies multiple interfaces and is only delivered to one address. This address can also be called one-to-one-of-many.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: Packets addressed to a multicast address are delivered to all interfaces identified by the multicast address, the same as in IPv4. It is also called a one-to-many address. You can always tell a multicast address in IPv6 because multicast addresses always start with FF.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing a unicast address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: These are your typical publicly routable addresses, just like a regular publicly routable address in IPv4.
test_questions.optc: These are like private addresses in IPv4 in that they are not meant to be routed.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface. For load balancing, multiple interfaces can use the same address.

test_questions.question: To enable OSPFv3, which of the following would you use?
test_questions.explanation: To enable OSPFv3, you enable the protocol as with RIPng. The command string is ipv6 ospf <process-id> area <area-id>.

test_questions.question: What multicast addresses does RIPng use?
test_questions.explanation: RIPng uses the multicast IPv6 address of FF02::9. If you remember the multicast addresses for IPv4, the numbers at the end of each IPv6 address are the same.

test_questions.question:
Which statement(s) about IPv6 addresses are true?
  Leading zeros are required.
  Two colons (::) are used to represent successive hexadecimal fields of zeros.
  Two colons (::) are used to separate fields.
  A single interface will have multiple IPv6 addresses of different types.
test_questions.explanation: In order to shorten the written length of an IPv6 address, successive fields of zeros may be replaced by double colons. In trying to shorten the address further, leading zeros may also be removed. Just as with IPv4, a single device's interface can have more than one address; with IPv6 there are more types of addresses and the same rule applies. There can be link-local, global unicast, and multicast addresses all assigned to the same interface.

test_questions.question: To enable RIPng, which of the following would you use?
test_questions.explanation: It's pretty simple to enable RIPng for IPv6. You configure it right on the interface where you want RIP to run with the ipv6 router rip number command.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing a global unicast address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: These are your typical publicly routable addresses, just like a regular publicly routable address in IPv4.
test_questions.optc: These are like private addresses in IPv4 in that they are not meant to be routed.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: Unlike unicast addresses, global unicast addresses are meant to be routed.

test_questions.question:
What two multicast addresses does OSPFv3 use?
 FF02::A  
 FF02::9
 FF02::5
 FF02::6
test_questions.explanation: Adjacencies and next-hop attributes now use link-local addresses, and OSPFv3 still uses multicast traffic to send its updates and acknowledgments with the addresses FF02::5 for OSPF routers and FF02::6 for OSPF designated routers. These are the replacements for 224.0.0.5 and 224.0.0.6, respectively.

test_questions.question: What multicast addresses does EIGRPv6 use?
test_questions.explanation: EIGRPv6's multicast address stayed very near the same. In IPv4 it was 224.0.0.10; now it is FF02::A (A=10 in hexadecimal notation).

test_questions.question:
To enable EIGRP, which of the following would you use?
  Router1(config-if)# ipv6 ospf 10 area 0.0.0.0
  Router1(config-if)# ipv6 router rip 1
  Router1(config)# ipv6 router eigrp 10
  Router1(config-rtr)# no shutdown
  Router1(config-if)# ipv6 eigrp 10
test_questions.explanation: Unlike RIPng and OSPFv3, you need to configure EIGRP both from global configuration mode and from interface mode, and you have to enable the command with the no shutdown command.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing a link-local address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: These are your typical publicly routable addresses, just like a regular publicly routable address in IPv4.
test_questions.optc: These are like private addresses in IPv4 in that they are not meant to be routed.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: Link-local addresses are meant for throwing together a temporary LAN for meetings or a small LAN that is not going to be routed but needs to share and access files and services locally.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing a unique local address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: These are your typical publicly routable addresses, just like a regular publicly routable address in IPv4.
test_questions.optc: These are like private addresses in IPv4 in that they are not meant to be routed.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes like link-local, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap. Unique local addresses were designed as a replacement for site-local addresses.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true when describing an anycast address?
test_questions.opta: Packets addressed to a unicast address are delivered to a single interface.
test_questions.optb: Packets are delivered to all interfaces identified by the address. This is also called one-to-many addresses.
test_questions.optc: This address identifies multiple interfaces and the anycast packet is only delivered to one address. This address can also be called one-to-one-of-many.
test_questions.optd: These addresses are meant for nonrouting purposes, but they are almost globally unique so it is unlikely they will have an address overlap.
test_questions.explanation: Anycast addresses identify multiple interfaces, which is the same as multicast; however, the big difference is that the anycast packet is only delivered to one address, the first one it finds defined in the terms of routing distance. This address can also be called one-to-one-of-many.

test_questions.question: You want to ping the loopback address of your local host(with IPv6). What will you type?
test_questions.explanation: The loopback address with IPv4 is 127.0.0.1. With IPv6, that address is ::1.

test_questions.question:
Which statement(s) about IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are true?
  An IPv6 address is 32 bits long, represented in hexidecimal.
  An IPv6 address is 128 bits long, represented in decimal.
  An IPv4 address is 32 bits long, represented in decimal.
  An IPv6 address is 128 bits long, represented in hexidecimal.
test_questions.explanation: IPv4 addresses are 32 bits long and are represented in decimal format. IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long and represented in hexadecimal format.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the command ip route 172.16.4.0 255.255.255.0 192.168.4.2?
  The command is used to establish a static route.
  The default administrative distance is used.
  The command is used to configure the default route.
  The subnet mask for the source address is 255.255.255.0.
test_questions.explanation:
Although answer D almost seems right, it is not; the mask is the mask used on the remote 
network, not the source network. Since there is no number at the end of the static route, it is 
using the default administrative distance of 1.

test_questions.question: Which command displays RIP routing updates?
test_questions.explanation: The debug ip rip command is used to show the Internet Protocol (IP) Routing Information Protocol (RIP) updates being sent and received on the router.

test_questions.question:
Which statement is true regarding classless routing protocols?
  The use of discontiguous networks is not allowed.
  The use of variable length subnet masks is permitted.
  RIPv1 is a classless routing protocol.
  IGRP supports classless routing within the same autonomous system.
  RIPv2 supports classless routing.
test_questions.explanation: Classful routing means that all hosts in the internetwork use the same mask. Classless routing means that you can use Variable Length Subnet Masks (VLSMs) and can also support discontiguous networking.

test_questions.question:
You have the following routing table. Which of the following networks will not be placed in the neighbor routing table?
R    192.168.30.0/24 [120/1] via 192.168.40.1, 00:00:12, Serial0
C    192.168.40.0/24 is directly connected, Serial0
     172.16.0.0/24 is subnetted, 1 subnets
C    172.16.30.0 is directly connected, Loopback0
R    192.168.20.0/24 [120/1] via 192.168.40.1, 00:00:12, Serial0
R    10.0.0.0/8 [120/15] via 192.168.40.1, 00:00:07, Serial0
C    192.168.50.0/24 is directly connected, Ethernet0
test_questions.optd: All of them will be placed in the neighbor routing table.
test_questions.explanation: The network 10.0.0.0 cannot be placed in the next router's routing table because it already is at 15 hops. One more hop would make the route 16 hops, and that is not valid in RIP networking.

test_questions.question: What is split horizon?
test_questions.opta: Information about a route should not be sent back in the direction from which the original update came.
test_questions.optb: It splits the traffic when you have a large bus (horizon) physical network.
test_questions.optc: It holds the regular updates from broadcasting to a downed link.
test_questions.optd: It prevents regular update messages from reinstating a route that has gone down.
test_questions.explanation: A split horizon will not advertise a route back to the same router it learned the route from.

test_questions.question: What command is used to stop RIP routing updates from exiting out an interface but still allow the interface to receive RIP route updates?
test_questions.explanation: The (config-router)#passive-interface command stops updates from being sent out an interface, but route updates are still received.

test_questions.question: Two connected routers are configured with RIP routing. What will be the result when a router receives a routing update that contains a higher-cost path to a network already in its routing table?
test_questions.opta: The updated information will be added to the existing routing table.
test_questions.optb: The update will be ignored and no further action will occur.
test_questions.optc: The updated information will replace the existing routing table entry.
test_questions.optd: The existing routing table entry will be deleted from the routing table and all routers will exchange routing updates to reach convergence.
test_questions.explanation: When a routing update is received by a router, the router first checks the administrative distance (AD) and always chooses the route with the lowest AD. However, if two routes are received and they both have the same AD, then the router will choose the one route with the lowest metrics, or in RIP's case, hop count.

test_questions.question: You type debug ip rip on your router console and see that 172.16.10.0 is being advertised to you with a metric of 16. What does this mean?
test_questions.optb: The route has a delay of 16 microseconds.
test_questions.optd: The route is queued at 16 messages a second.
test_questions.explanation: You cannot have 16 hops on a RIP network by default. If you receive a route advertised with a metric of 16, this means it is inaccessible.

test_questions.question:
The Corporate router receives an IP packet with a source IP address of 192.168.214.20 and a destination address of 192.168.22.3. Looking at the output from the Corporate router, what will the router do with this packet?
Corp#sh ip route
[output cut]
R    192.168.215.0 [120/2] via 192.168.20.2, 00:00:23, Serial0/0
R    192.168.115.0 [120/1] via 192.168.20.2, 00:00:23, Serial0/0
R    192.168.30.0 [120/1] via 192.168.20.2, 00:00:23, Serial0/0
C    192.168.20.0 is directly connected, Serial0/0
C    192.168.214.0 is directly connected, FastEthernet0/0
test_questions.optb: The packet will be routed out the S0/0 interface.
test_questions.optc: The router will broadcast looking for the destination.
test_questions.optd: The packet will be routed out the Fa0/0 interface.
test_questions.explanation: Since the routing table shows no route to the 192.168.22.0 network, the router will discard the packet and send an ICMP destination unreachable message out interface FastEthernet 0/0, which is the source LAN where the packet originated from.

test_questions.question: If your routing table has a static, a RIP, and an IGRP route to the same network, which route will be used to route packets by default?
test_questions.explanation: Static routes have an administrative distance of 1 by default. Unless you change this, a static route will always be used over any other found route. IGRP has an administrative distance of 100, and RIP has an administrative distance of 120, by default.

test_questions.question: What is route poisoning?
test_questions.opta: It sends back the protocol received from a router as a poison pill, which stops the regular updates.
test_questions.optb: It is information received from a router that can't be sent back to the originating router.
test_questions.optc: It prevents regular update messages from reinstating a route that has just come up.
test_questions.optd: It describes when a router sets the metric for a downed link to infinity.
test_questions.explanation: Another way to avoid problems caused by inconsistent updates and to stop network loops is route poisoning. When a network goes down, the distance-vector routing protocol initiates route poisoning by advertising the network with a metric of 16, or unreachable (sometimes referred to as infinite).

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding RIPv2?
test_questions.opta: It has a lower administrative distance than RIPv1.
test_questions.optc: It has the same timers as RIPv1.
test_questions.optd: It is harder to configure than RIPv1.
test_questions.explanation: RIPv2 is pretty much just like RIPv1. It has the same administrative distance and timers and is configured just like RIPv1.

test_questions.question: A network administrator views the output from the show ip route command. A network that is advertised by both RIP and IGRP appears in the routing table flagged as an IGRP route. Why is the RIP route to this network not used in the routing table?
test_questions.opta: IGRP has a faster update timer.
test_questions.optb: IGRP has a lower administrative distance.
test_questions.optc: RIP has a higher metric value for that route.
test_questions.optd: The IGRP route has fewer hops.
test_questions.explanation: RIP has an administrative distance (AD) of 120, while IGRP has an administrative distance of 100, so the router will discard any route with a higher AD than 100.

test_questions.question:
What does RIPv2 use to prevent routing loops?
  CIDR
  Split horizon
  Authentication
  Classless masking
  Holddown timers
test_questions.explanation: RIPv2 uses the same timers and loop-avoidance schemes as RIPv1. Split horizon is used to stop an update from being sent out the same interface it was received on. Holddown timers allow time for a network to become stable in the case of a flapping link.

test_questions.question:
Which two of the following are true regarding the distance-vector and link-state routing protocols?
  Link state sends its complete routing table out all active interfaces on periodic time intervals.
  Distance vector sends its complete routing table out all active interfaces on periodic time intervals.
  Link state sends updates containing the state of its own links to all routers in the internetwork.
  Distance vector sends updates containing the state of its own links to all routers in the internetwork.
test_questions.explanation: The distance-vector routing protocol sends its complete routing table out all active interfaces at periodic time intervals. Link-state routing protocols send updates containing the state of its own links to all routers in the internetwork.

test_questions.question:
IGRP uses which of the following as default parameters for finding the best path to a remote network?
  Hop count
  MTU
  Cumulative interface delay
  STP
  Path bandwidth value
test_questions.explanation: IGRP uses bandwidth and delay of the line, by default, to determine the best path to a remote network. Delay of the line can sometimes be called the cumulative interface delay.

test_questions.question:
Network 206.143.5.0 was assigned to the Acme Company to connect to its ISP. The administrator of Acme would like to configure one router with the commands to access the Internet. Which commands could be configured on the Gateway router to allow Internet access to the entire network?
 Gateway(config)# ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 206.143.5.2
 Gateway(config)# router rip
 Gateway(config-router)# network 206.143.5.0
 Gateway(config-router)# network 206.143.5.0 default
test_questions.explanation: There are actually three different ways to configure the same default route, but only two are shown in the answer. First, you can set a default route with the 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 mask and then specify the next hop, as in option A. Or you can use 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 and use the exit interface instead of the next hop. Finally, you can use option D with the ip default-network command.

test_questions.question:
You have your laptop directly connected into a router's Ethernet port. Which of the following are among the requirements for the copy flash tftp command to be successful?
  TFTP server software must be running on the router.
  TFTP server software must be running on your laptop.
  The Ethernet cable connecting the laptop directly into the router's Ethernet port must be a straight-through cable.
  The laptop must be on the same subnet as the router's Ethernet interface.
  The copy flash tftp command must be supplied the IP address of the laptop.
test_questions.explanation: Before you back up an IOS image to a laptop directly connected to a router's Ethernet port, make sure the TFTP server software is running on your laptop, that the Ethernet cable is a "crossover," and that the laptop is in the same subnet as the router's Ethernet port, and then you can use the copy flash tftp command from your laptop.

test_questions.question:
What information is displayed by the show hosts command?
  Temporary DNS entries
  The names of the routers created using the hostname command
  The IP addresses of workstations allowed to access the router
  Permanent name-to-address mappings created using the ip host command
  The length of time a host has been connected to the router via Telnet
test_questions.explanation: The show hosts command provides information on temporary DNS entries and permanent name-to-address mappings created using the ip host command.

test_questions.question:
You are unsuccessful in telnetting into a remote device. What could the problem be?
  IP addresses are incorrect.
  Access control list is filtering Telnet.
  There is a defective serial cable.
  The VTY password is missing.
test_questions.explanation: The best answers, the ones you need to remember, are that either an access control list is filtering the Telnet session or the VTY password is not set on the remote device.

test_questions.question:
Which three commands can be used to check LAN connectivity problems on a router?
 show interfaces
 show ip route
 tracert
 ping
 dns lookups
test_questions.explanation: The tracert command is a Windows command and will not work on a router! A router uses the traceroute command.

test_questions.question: If you want to have more than one Telnet session open at the same time, what keystroke combination would you use?
test_questions.explanation: To keep open one or more Telnet sessions, use the Ctrl+Shift+6 and then X keystroke combination.

test_questions.question: Which command will copy the IOS to a backup host on your network?
test_questions.explanation: To copy the IOS to a backup host, which is stored in flash memory by default, use the copy flash tftp command.

test_questions.question: Which command loads a new version of the Cisco IOS into a router?
test_questions.explanation: The command copy tftp flash will allow you to copy a new IOS into flash memory on your router.

test_questions.question: You are troubleshooting a connectivity problem in your corporate network and want to isolate the problem. You suspect that a router on the route to an unreachable network is at fault. What IOS user exec command should you issue?
test_questions.explanation: The command traceroute (trace for short), which can be issued from user mode or privileged mode, is used to find the path a packet takes through an internetwork and will also show you where the packet stops because of an error on a router.

test_questions.question: The configuration register setting of 0x2102 provides what function to a router?
test_questions.opta: Tells the router to boot into ROM monitor mode
test_questions.optc: Tells the router to look in NVRAM for the boot sequence
test_questions.optd: Boots the IOS from a TFTP server
test_questions.explanation: The default configuration setting of 0x2102 tells the router to look in NVRAM for the boot sequence.

test_questions.question: You telnet to a router and make your necessary changes; now you want to end the Telnet session. What command do you type in?
test_questions.explanation: Since the question never mentioned anything about a suspended session, you can assume that the Telnet session is still open, and you would just type exit to close the session.

test_questions.question: Which command displays the configuration register setting?
test_questions.explanation: The show version command provides you with the current configuration register setting.

test_questions.question: What should the configuration register value be after you successfully complete the password recovery procedure and return the router to normal operation?
test_questions.explanation: All Cisco routers have a default configuration register setting of 0x2102, which tells the router to load the IOS from flash memory and the configuration from NVRAM.

test_questions.question: You telnet into a remote device and type debug ip rip, but no output from the debug command is seen. What could the problem be?
test_questions.opta: You must type the show ip rip command first.
test_questions.optb: IP addressing on the network is incorrect.
test_questions.optc: You must use the terminal monitor command.
test_questions.optd: Debug output is sent only to the console.
test_questions.explanation: To see console messages through your Telnet session, you must enter the terminal monitor command.

test_questions.question: What does the command o/r 0x2142 provide?
test_questions.opta: It is used to restart the router.
test_questions.optb: It is used to bypass the configuration in NVRAM.
test_questions.optc: It is used to enter ROM Monitor mode.
test_questions.optd: It is used to view the lost password.
test_questions.explanation: The default configuration setting is 0x2102, which tells the router to load the IOS from flash and the configuration from NVRAM. 0x2142 tells the router to bypass the configuration in NVRAM so that you can perform password recovery.

test_questions.question: You save the configuration on a router with the copy running-config startup-config command and reboot the router. The router, however, comes up with a blank configuration. What can the problem be?
test_questions.opta: You didn't boot the router with the correct command.
test_questions.optc: The configuration register setting is incorrect.
test_questions.optd: The newly upgraded IOS is not compatible with the hardware of the router.
test_questions.explanation: If you save a configuration and reload the router and it comes up either in setup mode or as a blank configuration, chances are you have the configuration register setting incorrect.

test_questions.question: The corporate office sends you a new router to connect, but upon connecting the console cable, you see that there is already a configuration on the router. What should be done before a new configuration is entered in the router?
test_questions.opta: RAM should be erased and the router restarted.
test_questions.optb: Flash should be erased and the router restarted.
test_questions.optc: NVRAM should be erased and the router restarted.
test_questions.optd: The new configuration should be entered and saved.
test_questions.explanation: Before you start to configure the router, you should erase the NVRAM with the erase startup-config command and then reload the router using the reload command.

test_questions.question: Which command will show you the IOS version running on your router?
test_questions.explanation: The best answer is show version, which shows you the IOS file running currently on your router. The show flash command shows you the contents of flash memory, not which file is running.

test_questions.question: You need to gather the IP address of a remote switch that is located in Hawaii. What can you do to find the address?
test_questions.opta: Issue the show ip arp command on the router connected to the switch.
test_questions.optb: Issue the show ip route command on the router connected to the switch.
test_questions.optc: Issue the show cdp neighbor command on the router connected to the switch.
test_questions.optd: Issue the show cdp neighbors detail command on the router connected to the switch.
test_questions.explanation: Although option A is certainly the "best" answer, unfortunately option  D will work just fine and your boss would probably prefer you to use the show cdp neighbors detail command.

test_questions.question: A network administrator wants to upgrade the IOS of a router without removing the image currently installed. What command will display the amount of memory consumed by the current IOS image and indicate whether there is enough room available to hold both the current and new images?
test_questions.explanation: The show flash command will provide you with the current IOS name and size and the size of flash memory.

test_questions.question: You copy a configuration from a network host to a router's RAM. The configuration looks correct, yet it is not working at all. What could the problem be?
test_questions.opta: You copied the wrong configuration into RAM.
test_questions.optb: You copied the configuration into flash memory instead.
test_questions.optc: The copy did not override the shutdown command in running-config.
test_questions.optd: The IOS became corrupted after the copy command was initiated.
test_questions.explanation: Since the configuration looks correct, you probably didn't screw up the copy job. However, when you perform a copy from a network host to a router, the interfaces are automatically shut down and need to be manually enabled with the no shutdown command.

test_questions.question: How long is an IPv6 address?
test_questions.explanation: An IPv6 address is 128 bits long.

test_questions.question: What flavor of Network Address Translation can be used to have one IP address allow many users to connect to the global Internet?
test_questions.explanation: Port Address Translation (PAT) allows a one-to-many approach to network address translation.

test_questions.question:
What are the two main types of access control lists (ACLs)?
  Standard
  IEEE
  Extended
  Specialized
test_questions.explanation: Standard and extended access control lists (ACLs) are used to configure security on a router.

test_questions.question: What command is used to create a backup configuration?
test_questions.explanation: The command to back up the configuration on a router is copy running-config startup-config.

test_questions.question:
You have 10 users plugged into a hub running 10Mbps half-duplex. There is a server connected to the switch running 10Mbps half-duplex as well. How much bandwidth does each 
host have to the server?
test_questions.explanation: Each device has 10 Mbps	to the server.

test_questions.question: Which WLAN IEEE specification allows up to 54Mbps at 2.4GHz?
test_questions.explanation: IEEE 802.11B is 2.4GHz, but with a maximum of only 11Mbps. IEEE 802.11G is in the 2.4GHz range, with a top speed of 54Mbps.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is the valid host range for the subnet on which the IP address 192.168.168.188 255.255.255.192 resides?
test_questions.explanation:
256 - 192 = 64. 64 + 64 = 128. 128 + 64 = 192. The subnet is 128, the broadcast address 
is 191, and the valid host range is the numbers in between, or 129-190.

test_questions.question: To back up an IOS, what command will you use?
test_questions.explanation: The command copy flash tftp will prompt you to back up an existing IOS in flash to a TFTP host.

test_questions.question: What protocol does PPP use to identify the Network layer protocol?
test_questions.explanation: Network Control Protocol is used to help identify the Network layer protocol used in the packet.

test_questions.question: Which of the following commands will allow you to set your Telnet password on a Cisco router?
test_questions.explanation: The command line vty 0 4 places you in a prompt that will allow you to set or change your Telnet password.

test_questions.question: Which protocol does DHCP use at the Transport layer?
test_questions.explanation: User Datagram Protocol is a connection network service at the Transport layer, and DHCP uses this connectionless service.

test_questions.question: Which command is used to determine if an IP access list is enabled on a particular interface?
test_questions.explanation: The show ip interface command will show you if any outbound or inbound interfaces have an access list set.

test_questions.question: Where is a hub specified in the OSI model?
test_questions.explanation: Hubs regenerate electrical signals, which are specified at the Physical layer.

test_questions.question: What does the passive command provide to dynamic routing protocols?
test_questions.opta: Stops an interface from sending or receiving periodic dynamic updates.
test_questions.optb: Stops an interface from sending periodic dynamic updates but not from receiving updates.
test_questions.optc: Stops the router from receiving any dynamic updates.
test_questions.optd: Stops the router from sending any dynamic updates.
test_questions.explanation: The passive command, short for passive-interface, stops regular updates from being sent out an interface. However, the interface can still receive updates.

test_questions.question: Which protocol is used to send a destination network unknown message back to originating hosts?
test_questions.explanation: ICMP is the protocol at the Network layer that is used to send messages back to an originating router.

test_questions.question: How often are BPDUs sent from a layer 2 device?
test_questions.explanation: Every 2 seconds, BPDUs are sent out from all active bridge ports by default.

test_questions.question: How many broadcast domains are created when you segment a network with a 12-port switch?
test_questions.explanation: By default, switches break up collision domains but are one large broadcast domain.

test_questions.question: What does the command routerA(config)#line cons 0 allow you to perform next?
test_questions.explanation: The command line console 0 places you at a prompt where you can then set your console user-mode password.

test_questions.question: Which router command allows you to view the entire contents of all access lists?
test_questions.explanation: To see the contents of all access lists, use the show access-lists command.

test_questions.question: Which class of IP address has the most host addresses available by default?
test_questions.explanation: Class A addressing provides 24 bits for host addressing.

test_questions.question: In a network with dozens of switches, how many root bridges would you have?
test_questions.explanation: You should have only one root bridge per network.

test_questions.question: What PPP protocol provides dynamic addressing, authentication, and multilink?
test_questions.explanation: Link Control Protocol in the PPP stack provides dynamic addressing, authentication, and multilink.

test_questions.question: What is a stub network?
test_questions.opta: A network with more than one exit point.
test_questions.optb: A network with more than one exit and entry point.
test_questions.optc: A network with only one entry and no exit point.
test_questions.optd: A network that has only one entry and exit point.
test_questions.explanation: Stub networks have only one connection to an internetwork. Only default routes can be set on a stub network or network loops may occur.

test_questions.question: If your router is facilitating a CSU/DSU, which of the following commands do you need to use to provide the router with a 64000bps serial link?
test_questions.explanation: The clock rate command is two words, and the speed of the line is in bps.

test_questions.question: Which one of the following is true regarding VLANs?
test_questions.opta: Two VLANs are configured by default on all Cisco switches.
test_questions.optb: VLANs only work if you have a complete Cisco switched internetwork. No off-brand switches are allowed.
test_questions.optc: You should not have more than 10 switches in the same VTP domain.
test_questions.optd: VTP is used to send VLAN information to switches in a configured VTP domain.
test_questions.explanation: Switches do not propagate VLAN information by default; you must configure the VTP domain. VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP) is used to propagate VLAN information across a trunk link.

test_questions.question: What does a VLAN do?
test_questions.opta: Acts as the fastest port to all servers.
test_questions.optb: Provides multiple collision domains on one switch port.
test_questions.optc: Breaks up broadcast domains in a layer 2 switch internetwork.
test_questions.optd: Provides multiple broadcast domains within a single collision domain.
test_questions.explanation: VLANs break up broadcast domains at layer 2.

test_questions.question: What is the main reason the OSI model was created?
test_questions.opta: To create a layered model larger than the DoD model.
test_questions.optb: So application developers can change only one layer's protocols at a time.
test_questions.optd: So Cisco could use the model.
test_questions.explanation: The primary reason the OSI model was created was so that different networks could inter-operate.

test_questions.question: How many collision domains are created when you segment a network with a 12-port switch?
test_questions.explanation: Layer 2 switching creates individual collision domains.

test_questions.question: What command will display the line, protocol, DLCI, and LMI information of an interface?
test_questions.explanation: The show interface command shows the line, protocol, DLCI, and LMI information of an interface.

test_questions.question: Which protocol does Ping use?
test_questions.explanation: ICMP is the protocol at the Network layer that is used to send echo requests and replies.

test_questions.question: Which command is used to upgrade an IOS on a Cisco router?
test_questions.explanation: The copy tftp flash command places a new file in flash memory, which is the default location for the Cisco IOS in Cisco routers.

test_questions.question: If you wanted to delete the configuration stored in NVRAM, what would you type?
test_questions.explanation: The command erase startup-config deletes the configuration stored in NVRAM.

test_questions.question:
What protocols are used to configure trunking on a switch?
  VLAN Trunking Protocol
  VLAN
  802.1Q
  ISL
test_questions.explanation: VTP is not right because it has nothing to do with trunking except that it sends VLAN information across a trunk link. 802.1Q and ISL are used to configure trunking on a port.

test_questions.question: Which command would you place on interface connected to the Internet?
test_questions.explanation: As in access-lists, you must configure your interfaces before NAT will provide any translations. On the inside networks you would use the command ip nat inside. On the outside interface, you will use the command ip nat outside.

test_questions.question: Which command will show you all the translations active on your router?
test_questions.explanation: The command show ip nat translations will show you the translation table containing all the active NAT entries.

test_questions.question: Which command would you place on interface on a private network?
test_questions.explanation: As in access-lists, you must configure your interfaces before NAT will provide any translations. On the inside networks you would use the command ip nat inside. On the outside interface, you will use the command ip nat outside.

test_questions.question: Port Address Translation is also termed what?
test_questions.explanation: Another term for port address translation is NAT Overload because that is the command used to enable port address translation.

test_questions.question: When creating a pool of global addresses, which of the following can be used instead of the netmask command?
test_questions.explanation: Instead of the netmask command, you can use the prefix-length <length> statement.

test_questions.question: Which of the following would be a good starting point for troubleshooting if your router is not translating?
test_questions.optc: Check your interfaces for the correct configuration.
test_questions.explanation: In order for NAT to provide translation services, you must have ip nat inside and ip nat outside configured on your router's interfaces.

test_questions.question: Which command will show you the summary of the NAT configuration?
test_questions.explanation: The show ip nat statistics command displays a summary of the NAT configuration as well as counts of active translation types, hits to an existing mapping, misses (causing an attempt to create a mapping), and expired translations.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be the destination host before translation?
test_questions.explanation: The host on the global network before translation is considered to be an outside local host.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be the address after translation?
test_questions.explanation: The host on the private network after translation is considered to be an inside global host.

test_questions.question:
Which are considered the methods of NAT?
  Static
  IP NAT pool
  Dynamic
  NAT double-translation
  Overload
test_questions.explanation: You can configure NAT three ways on a Cisco router: static, dynamic, and NAT Overload (PAT).

test_questions.question: Which command will allow you to see real-time translations on your router?
test_questions.explanation: The command debug ip nat will show you in real time the translations occurring on your router.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following would be good reasons to run NAT?
  You need to connect to the Internet and your hosts don't have globally unique IP addresses.
  You change to a new ISP that requires you to renumber your network.
  You don't want any hosts connecting to the Internet.
  You require two intranets with duplicate addresses to merge.
test_questions.explanation: The most popular use of NAT is if you want to connect to the Internet and you don't want hosts to have global (real) IP addresses, but option B and D are correct as well.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are advantages of using NAT?
  Translation introduces switching path delays.
  Conserves legally registered addresses.
  Causes loss of end-to-end IP traceability.
  Increases flexibility when connecting to the Internet.
  Certain applications will not function with NAT enabled.
  Reduces address overlap occurrence.
test_questions.explanation: NAT is not perfect, but there are some advantages. It conserves global addresses, which allow us to add millions of hosts to the Internet without "real" IP addresses. This provides flexibility in our corporate networks. NAT can also allow you to use the same subnet more than once in the same network without overlapping networks.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be the address before translation?
test_questions.explanation: The host on the private network before translation is considered to be an inside local host.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are disadvantages of using NAT?
  Translation introduces switching path delays.
  Conserves legally registered addresses.
  Causes loss of end-to-end IP traceability.
  Increases flexibility when connecting to the Internet.
  Certain applications will not function with NAT enabled.
  Reduces address overlap occurrence.
test_questions.explanation: NAT is not perfect and can cause some issues in some networks, but most networks work just fine. NAT can cause delays and troubleshooting problems, and some applications just won't work.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is considered to be the destination host after translation?
test_questions.explanation: The host on the global network after translation is considered to be an outside global host.

test_questions.question: Which command will create a dynamic pool named Todd that will provide you with 30 global addresses?
test_questions.explanation: The command ip nat pool <name> creates the pool that hosts can use to get onto the global Internet. What makes option B correct is that the range 171.16.10.65 through 171.16.10.94 includes 30 hosts, but the mask has to match 30 hosts as well, and that mask is 255.255.255.224. Option C is wrong because the pool name has a lower case "T" in the pool name. Pool name's are case sensitive.

test_questions.question: Which command will clear all the translations active on your router?
test_questions.explanation: The command clear ip nat translations * will clear all the active NAT entries in your translation table.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding access lists applied to an interface?
test_questions.opta: You can place as many access lists as you want on any interface until you run out of memory.
test_questions.optb: You can apply only one access list on any interface.
test_questions.optc: One access list may be configured, per direction, for each layer 3 protocol configured on an interface.
test_questions.optd: You can apply two access lists to any interface.
test_questions.explanation: A Cisco router has rules regarding the placement of access lists on a router interface. You can place one access list per direction for each layer 3 protocol configured on an interface.

test_questions.question: Which command would you use to apply an access list to a router interface?
test_questions.explanation: To apply an access list, the proper command is ip access-group 101 in.

test_questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a standard IP access list?
test_questions.explanation: Standard IP access lists use the numbers 1-99 and 1300-1999 and filter based on source IP address only. Option C is incorrect because the mask must be in wildcard format.

test_questions.question: You need to create an access list that will prevent hosts in the network range of 192.168.160.0 to 192.168.191.0. Which of the following lists will you use?
test_questions.explanation: The range of 192.168.160.0 to 192.168.191.0 is a block size of 32. The network address is 192.168.160.0 and the mask would be 255.255.224.0, which for an access list must be a wildcard format of 0.0.31.255. The 31 is used for a block size of 32. The wildcard is always one less than the block size.

test_questions.question: You are working on a router that has established privilege levels that restrict access to certain functions. You discover that you are not able to execute the command show running-configuration. How can you view and confirm the access lists that have been applied to the Ethernet 0 interface on your router?
test_questions.explanation: The only command that shows which access lists have been applied to an interface is show ip interface Ethernet 0. The command show access-lists displays all configured access lists, and show ip access-lists displays all configured IP access lists, but neither command indicates whether the displayed access lists have been applied to an interface.

test_questions.question: What command will permit SMTP mail to only host 1.1.1.1?
test_questions.optc: access-list 10 permit tcp any host 1.1.1.1 eq smtp
test_questions.optd: access-list 110 permit tcp any host 1.1.1.1 eq smtp
test_questions.explanation: When trying to find the best answer to an access-list question, always check the access-list number and then the protocol. When filtering to an upper-layer protocol, you must use an extended list, numbers 100-199 and 2000-2699. Also, when you filter to an upper-layer protocol, you must use either tcp or udp in the protocol field. If it says ip in the protocol field, you cannot filter to an upper-layer protocol. SMTP uses TCP.

test_questions.question: You want to create a standard access list that denies the subnet of the following host: 172.16.50.172/20. Which of the following would you start your list with?
test_questions.explanation: First, you must know that a /20 is 255.255.240.0, which is a block size of 16 in the third octet. Counting by 16s, this makes our subnet 48 in the third octet, and the wildcard for the third octet would be 15 since the wildcard is always one less than the block size.

test_questions.question: What router command allows you to determine whether an IP access list is enabled on a particular interface?
test_questions.explanation: Only the show ip interface command will tell you which interfaces have access lists applied. show access-lists will not show you which interfaces have an access list applied.

test_questions.question: You have created a named access list called Blocksales. Which of the following is a valid command for applying this to packets trying to enter interface s0 of your router?
test_questions.explanation: Using a named access list just replaces the number used when applying the list to the router's interface. ip access-group Blocksales in is correct.

test_questions.question: You want to create a standard access list that denies the subnet of the following host: 172.16.144.17/21. Which of the following would you start your list with?
test_questions.explanation: First, you must know that a /21 is 255.255.248.0, which is a block size of 8 in the third octet. Counting by eight, this makes our subnet 144 in the third octet, and the wildcard for the third octet would be 7 since the wildcard is always one less than the block size.

test_questions.question:
You configure the following access list:
access-list 110 deny tcp 10.1.1.128 0.0.0.63 any eq smtp
access-list 110 deny tcp any eq 23
int ethernet 0
ip access-group 110 out
What will the result of this access list be?
test_questions.opta: Email and Telnet will be allowed out E0.
test_questions.optb: Email and Telnet will be allowed in E0.
test_questions.optc: Everything but email and Telnet will be allowed out E0.
test_questions.optd: No IP traffic will be allowed out E0.
test_questions.explanation: If you add an access list to an interface and you do not have at least one permit statement, then you will effectively shut down the interface because of the implicit deny any at the end of every list.

test_questions.question: You want to create a standard access list that denies the subnet of the following host: 172.16.198.94/19. Which of the following would you start your list with?
test_questions.explanation: First, you must know that a /19 is 255.255.224.0, which is a block size of 32 in the third octet. Counting by 32, this makes our subnet 192 in the third octet, and the wildcard for the third octet would be 31 since the wildcard is always one less than the block size.

test_questions.question: If you wanted to deny all Telnet connections to only network 192.168.10.0, which command could you use?
test_questions.explanation: The extended access list ranges are 100-199 and 2000-2699, so the access-list number of 100 is valid. Telnet uses TCP, so the protocol TCP is valid. Now you just need to look for the source and destination address. Only the third option has the correct sequence of parameters. Answer B may work, but the question specifically states "only" to network 192.168.10.0, and the wildcard in answer B is too broad.

test_questions.question: Which router command allows you to view the entire contents of all access lists?
test_questions.explanation: The show access-lists command will allow you to view the entire contents of all access lists, but it will not show you the interfaces to which the access lists are applied.

test_questions.question: Which of the following access lists will allow only HTTP traffic into network 196.15.7.0?
test_questions.opta: access-list 100 permit tcp any 196.15.7.0 0.0.0.255 eq www
test_questions.optb: access-list 10 deny tcp any 196.15.7.0 eq www
test_questions.explanation: The first thing to check in a question like this is the access-list number. Right away, you can see that the second option is wrong because it is using a standard IP access-list number. The second thing to check is the protocol. If you are filtering by upper-layer protocol, then you must be using either UDP or TCP; this eliminates the fourth option. The third and last answers have the wrong syntax.

test_questions.question:
Which of the following are valid ways to refer only to host 172.16.30.55 in an IP access list?
  172.16.30.55 0.0.0.255
  172.16.30.55 0.0.0.0
  any 172.16.30.55
  host 172.16.30.55
  0.0.0.0 172.16.30.55
  ip any 172.16.30.55
test_questions.explanation: The wildcard 0.0.0.0 tells the router to match all four octets. This wildcard format alone can be replaced with the host command.

test_questions.question: If you wanted to deny FTP access from network 200.200.10.0 to network 200.199.11.0 but allow everything else, which of the following command strings is valid?
test_questions.opta:
access-list 110 deny 200.200.10.0 to network 200.199.11.0 eq ftp
access-list 111 permit ip any 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255
test_questions.explanation: Extended IP access lists use numbers 100-199 and 2000-2699 and filter based on source and destination IP address, protocol number, and port number.
